media.caption: Old problem, new challenge!
media.credit: Yuguo Li - The University of Hong Kong

text.headline: Airborne/Aerosol: Old problem, new challenge!
text.text:
SARS-CoV-2 transmission: a inconsistency/ambiguity?
No authorities have admitted airborne transmission yet.
But all national and international authorities recommended maintaining good ventilation. If not airborne, why ventilate? - Yuguo Li

media.caption: Pringle - Observations on the diseases of the army.

text.headline: Fresh air known to be important for army medical camps
text.text: As long ago as 1749, Pringle, a doctor, studied medical army camp hospitals. He found that fresh air was important to stop disease spread

media.caption: Charles Chapin - short treatise on scarlet fever

text.headline: Scarlet fever known to occasionally be airborne
text.text: Charles Chapin, who would later promote that most transmission was droplet borne, still appreciated himself that scarlet fever could occasionally transmit reach the second floor of a house and was therefore airborne

media.caption: Book Cover: Sources and modes of infection - Charles Chapin MD

text.headline: Chapin proposes that pathogens live in our bodies, and are transmitted from person to person
text.text: Charles Chapin, medical doctor in Rhode Island, pushes the view that pathogens don't live long outside the body and therefore are transmitted person to person, and not simply freely in the air. He sees most transmission happening at short range, which he calls 'close contact' and suggests it is therefore common sense that this means diseases are transmitted by droplets. He is wrong about this. As an aside, he does not think fomites account for much transmission.

media.caption: Wells curves for different relative humiditie

text.headline: W. F. Wells founding the droplet nuclei science in 1934
text.text: Wells thought that droplets smaller a certain size would quickly evaporate, leaving a dry residue that drifts in the air. Since droplets from an infected person may contain infectious bacteria or viruses, these processes influence transmission of respiratory diseases

text.headline: Guinea pigs proof of airborne transmission of Tuberculosis (TB)
text.text: Richard L. Riley - first hand account of 1962 proof by Riley, Mills, O'Grady, Sultan, Willstadt, Shivpuri, and Wells: 'Infectiousness of air from a tuberculosis ward'. That study: here

media.caption: capture from the full report (Bloch) - see 'airborne' in text

text.headline: One child infects seven in a physician's office #airborne
text.text: Measles outbreak in a pediatric practice: airborne transmission in an office setting. The study goes on to warn of modern office buildings having recirculated air

text.headline: Three children catch measles at doctor's office
text.text: Three children caught measles at a doctor's office. They were there an hour after the sick child left.

text.headline: EXPOSURE TO MEASLES FEARED AT SPORTS EVENT
text.text: Thousands of people involved in the International Special Olympics last month may have been exposed to measles, one of the most easily transmitted communicable diseases, according to the Minnesota Health Department.

media.caption: Kids not infected with anything hopefully

text.headline: A school outbreak of Norwalk-like virus: evidence for airborne transmission
text.text:
This study confirms the importance of vomiting in the transmission
of NLV and provides evidence that direct infection with aerosolized viral particles occurs

media.caption: A man who spent one night at Hong Kong's Metropole Hotel (left) spread SARS to other ninth floor guests

text.headline: Metropole Hotel 2003 (SARS)
text.text: [Study] 21 infected by one guest who vomited in a corridor. Excerpt: ... At the time, it was not clear if the causative agent was being transmitted by airborne particles, as measles and tuberculosis spread ...

media.caption: Airflow study of MERS in South Korean hospital

text.headline: South Korean Hospital (MERS)
text.text: Airflow analysis of Pyeongtaek St Mary's Hospital during hospitalization of the first Middle East respiratory syndrome patient in Korea
